The Crown applied to have the witness declared adverse pursuant to s. 9 of the Canada Evidence Act on the basis that she has demonstrated a hostile attitude towards the position of the Crown and hascontradicted in a substantial way, her prior video-taped statement to police officers made shortly after her arrest. The defence sought to use her prior statement as substantive evidence. HELD: 1)The credibility of the witness was determined with respect to her prior statements as to her conduct during and after her imprisonment. 2)The evidence of the police officer who had administered the contemporaneous oath was not administered prior to the taking of the statement and there was no warning provided at that time of her arrest to the effect that her statements would be unreliable. 3)The oath was never administered prior before the taking and was not given post-sentence. 4)The reliability threshold can be met in the absence of an oath where appropriate substitutes for the oath exist. 5)The witness's prior statement may be introduced in evidence for the substantive truth of its subjectents. 6)The statements that were not given to the defence were not credible. 7)The affidavit was not credible as there was insufficient solemnity attached to the occasion of her swearing. 8)The affidavits were not administered post-Sentence. 9)The validity of the statements was determined on the balance of probabilities.
